clinical_study.brief_title: Effectiveness of a Diuretic Algorithm in Clinical Stability in Heart Failure Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Effectiveness of a Diuretic Algorithm in Clinical Stability and Readmissions in Heart Failure Patients

brief_summary.textblock: In heart failure (HF), the leading cause of decompensation and subsequent visits to emergency rooms and hospital readmission is congestion. The Diuretic Treatment Algorithm (DTA) was developed for adjustment of diuretics conducted by telephone by North-American nurses, with a focus on non-pharmacological and pharmacological evaluation and home management of patients with HF. This algorithm has proven to be an effective tool in preventing decompensation, significantly decreasing the rates of readmissions and 50% of hospitalizations related to HF at 30 days. In Brazil DTA proved applicable in clinical practice after adaption and appears to result in better congestion management in patients with heart failure. The clinical effectiveness of the tool should be tested in a larger patient sample aiming assess the Effectiveness of the algorithm diuretic in clinical stability and readmissions in heart failure patients.

detailed_description.textblock:
In heart failure (HF), the leading cause of decompensation and subsequent visits to emergency rooms and hospital readmission is congestion. The identification of early signs and symptoms interrupts progressive exacerbation of the condition, with a direct impact on reduced costs, hospitalizations and mortality. One of the strategies that has already been proven to prevent exacerbation is intensive and systematic monitoring through telephone and home visits. In light of this, the Diuretic Treatment Algorithm (DTA) was developed for adjustment of diuretics conducted by telephone by North-American nurses, with a focus on non-pharmacological and pharmacological evaluation and home management of patients with HF. In Brazil DTA proved applicable in clinical practice after adaption and appears to result in better congestion management in patients with heart failure. This study aims to evaluate the Effectiveness of the algorithm diuretic in clinical stability and readmissions in heart failure patients.
The hypothesis is that patients randomized to the intervention group (IG) - management by DTA followed with four 30-day telephone contacts reduce the signs and symptoms of congestion, body weight, submit improvement in functional class and fewer emergency room visits or readmissions when compared to the Control Group (CG) which will fit diuretic as medical management (no protocol) and no telephone contact followed during the same period. In 90 days everyone will receive a telephone call to assess hospitalizations at the end of the period.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.measure: Emergency room visits for Heart Failure
primary_outcome.description: The outcomes will be evaluated every phone contact (1 per week) in the intervention group, and after 30 days in the final evaluation for both groups

secondary_outcome.description: Secondary outcomes will be assessed at the end of 90 days using data from medical records and a single telephone contact for both groups.

arm_group.description: In the control group, the patients do not receive phone calls neither advising on non-pharmacological treatment; The medication is adjusted by the doctor during the initial evaluation of study baseline.

The intervention group is conducted by a nurse in a systematic way during one time per week. If signs and symptoms of congestion, the dose of diuretic ( furosemide ) is revised , nonpharmacological guidelines are provided. According to the algorithm 1KG weight changes are indicative of modifying the diuretic dose , with the addition or reduction 1 tablet a day.

intervention.description: The intervention group is conducted by a nurse in a systematic way during one time per week. If signs and symptoms of congestion, the dose of diuretic ( furosemide ) is revised , nonpharmacological guidelines are provided. According to the algorithm 1KG weight changes are indicative of modifying the diuretic dose , with the addition or reduction 1 tablet a day (1 tablet equivalent to 40 miligrams of furosemide)
This group received just diuretic adjusted (Furosemide 40 miligrams) by the doctor on the baseline.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients of both genders
- Age ≥ 18 years
- Diagnosed with systolic HF
- Able to monitor body weight at home
- Using furosemide
Exclusion Criteria:
- Those who are not able to make return visits or participate in telephone contact, and those on renal replacement therapy.
